Bowser and Bowser Jr. are then seen using some kind of vacuum cleaner on a spacecraft to steel the Mini Stars. Now it's up to Mario and his friends to get them back, through playing a party game.

In the game, four players ride in a vehicle, and the captain of the vehicle rolls the dice block to move forward. Each board has a destination, but there are a variety of directions to take. Players can fight bosses including Bowser himself, or other classic foes such as Blooper or Wiggler. Players can also collect Party Points to spend on unlockables such as new boards. The game also includes a solo mode and a Mini-game mode where you can play the mini-games directly.
title: Mario Party 9

description:
Pearl Harbor Trilogy: 1941: Red Sun Rising is a reworking of the 2007 game Attack on Pearl Harbor of which Red Sun Rising is the first part of a planned trilogy. It contains two of the four campaigns of the original game (USA and Japan) and offers a neutral take on the event, offering players to choose either side.

The game is a motion-controlled flight simulator in which players can have random dogfights. The game is not meant to be a realistic simulator as aircraft carry unlimited ammunition, limited only by overheating (machine guns) and reloading times (rockets, bombs, and torpedoes). Unlike the original game there are no multiplayer options and the difficulty level has been heightened. The game can be played through three different control schemes: Wii Remote, Classic Controller and/or Wii Remote + Nunchuk.
title: Pearl Harbor Trilogy: 1941: Red Sun Rising

description: Ghost Mania is a falling block puzzle game where players match colored ghost blocks with neutral solid color blocks to clear the level. Color stacks can be built and expanded in any direction and in any number. The game includes three single player modes; a relaxed and thoughtful Puzzle mode as well as a story-driven Arcade mode and the Endless mode. It also features two-player local multiplayer with the Battle, Enduro and Ghost modes. The story focuses on the misadventures of Becky and Tim, a pair of ghost guardians who have just lost their jobs and been kicked out of the Spirit World (where all ghosts live).
title: Ghost Mania

description:
Food Network: Cook or Be Cooked! is an interactive cooking title utilizing the Wii's motion controls as you, the player, mimic cooking gestures as you replicate authentic recipes endorsed by the American cooking specialty television channel Food Network. The game contains twelve meals with multiple dishes each that are prepared by going through various mini-games. You are judged not only on how well you perform the gestures, but also must use strategy to ensure that all components of the meal come out on time and at the proper temperature.

The game can be played in singleplayer, in the Pass and Play mode with four people working in a single recipe, and in multiplayer as a cook-off between two people. The game features likenesses and voice-overs of Food Network stars Susie Fogelson and chef Mory Thomas.
title: Food Network:  Cook or Be Cooked!

description:
Pop 'Em Drop 'Em Samegame is a variant of SameGame, a puzzle game concept that was introduced with the game Chain Shot in 1985.

The player is presented with a board full of blocks and the goal is to remove them all. To remove blocks the player simply clicks on a group of two or more blocks of the same colour. As blocks are removed those above will fall down and fill in the empty space. When columns are emptied the blocks will fill in from the right. The game goes on until there are no more blocks that can be removed. When all blocks on the board have been removed the player will move on to a new board. The player scores for each block removed and larger groups of blocks give the most points. Different options exist that alter the game's difficulty. This include the size of the board (from 9x9 to 22x12) and number of colours (3-5). It is also possible to use bombs that can blow up unwanted blocks.

The game features multiplayer for up to four players locally. There are three different multiplayer modes: fame game, shame game and blame game. Fame game is most similar to the single player and the player with the highest score wins. Shame game turns it all around; here the player with the lowest score wins. In these modes a player can colourblock the other players by clearing large numbers of blocks. In the blame game all players play on the same board.
title: Pop 'Em Drop 'Em Samegame

description:
This limited edition comes in a cardboard box and includes:

  • Pandora's Tower
  • Steelbook cover
  • Art book
title: Pandora's Tower (Limited Edition)

description:
FlatOut is an adaptation for the Wii of the long-running racing series, combining fast-paced racing with ramming opponents and destroying objects in the environment. It contains four different game modes: Racing, Car Basher, Battle Arena and Stunt. There are twelve tracks in total, divided over four chapters. They include environments such as a busy financial district, an industrial port, and villages in Southern Europe.

Racing is the regular game mode where races have to be won by finishing in first place or wrecking all opponents. Cars have a health meter and there is a damage model with visual clues to the condition. In Car Basher the player's driver chooses one of the twelve available weapons such as a baseball bat or a crowbar, and needs to trash the opponent's car with as much damage as possible before time runs out to win the car. Battle Arena has Destruction Derby-like environments with booby traps, ramps, loopings, and fire for much more destructive gameplay. The main goal is to lure or push other cars into traps. The final game mode is called Stunt and offers classic gameplay from the series where the driver has to be ejected through the windshield at the right angle to reach targets.

The cars are controlled by holding the Wii Remote horizontally and tilting it to steer. The game can be played locally in multiplayer through a split-screen.
title: FlatOut

description: ZhuZhu Pets: Featuring The Wild Bunch is a 2.5D side scrolling platform adventure through 36 levels. It is based on the American line of plush Zhu Zhu Pets robotic hamster toys. Players control a hamster through different levels with no enemies or obstacles that can cause the hamster to die. Instead it focuses on collecting items such as coins and gems, and solving minor puzzle elements in the environment to further exploration. Keys need to be found to open the exit of each level. There are also members of the Wild Bunch that need to be tagged as they try to evade the main character. Each level also contains three hidden stars in secret location. It is possible to drive Zhu Zhu vehicles including speedboats, convertibles, and hamster balls. Additionally pieces of equipment can be used to expand the gameplay. These include super capes, snow skis, vacuum backpacks, jet-packs and safari suits.
title: ZhuZhu Pets Featuring the Wild Bunch

description:
Nerf N-Strike is a rail shooter game where the player moves through a shooting gallery with different challenges aiming at both stationary and moving targets with a nerf gun. N-Strike refers to a line of toys of Hasbro for nerf guns. The game is set in a secret training facility with different levels and there are over 25 different nerf weapons to unlock. The selection of guns includes real and fictional ones. Each guns has a different handling and ammo includes balls, darts and bullets. As with a real nerf gun, bullets do not travel into a straight line and the player has to compensate the floating by aiming a little higher for enemies in the distance.

The opponents are generally robots and the player only needs to shoot, the camera and general movement is done automatically. In most of the sequences the gun is visible but at specific moments a scope-like zoomed in view appears. In the main mission mode the goal is to beat the score of a challenger. There are also mini-games and smaller challenges that involve painting rolling spheres to make them explode and nailing a target cube through a stack of blocks. It is possible to team up with up to three other players to defeat the N-Strike Elite rivals and B.O.B. the cybernetic training bot.

The game is bundled with the Nerf Switch Shot EXE-3 gun. The game is also compatible with regular N-Strike guns as the pneumatic pod can be removed to introduce the Wii Remote and to turn it into a light gun. The bundled gun can also be used to shoot regular darts.
title: Nerf N-Strike

description:
This compilation contains:

  • Nerf N-Strike
  • Nerf N-Strike Elite
  • Nerf Switch Shot EXE-3 gun and Red Reveal decoder lens
title: Nerf N-Strike: Double Blast Bundle

description:
Grand Slam Tennis is a tennis game that features venues from all four Grand Slam tournaments; the Australian Open, the French Open, Wimbledon and the US Open. It includes 14 of the top players at the time of release (e.g. Federer, Nadal and the Williams sisters) and 9 retired tennis legends (e.g. Sampras, McEnroe, Navratilova). The game is played with the Wii Remote and Nunchuck and also has full support for Wii MotionPlus where the timing of the swings is measured. Despite the cartoonish character models it aims to be a tennis simulation game with a learning curve, especially when played with the Wii MotionPlus.

There are four game modes:* The main career mode allows the player to customize their own character then travel to each of the 4 tournaments and attempt to win the Grand Slam.

  • Party mode is a collection of mini-games for one to four players. Each features a variation on the rules of tennis.

  • Play Now allows one to four players to choose their characters, venues and game length and settings for a quick game.

  • Online mode has players competing against each other in ranked or unranked matches. Winning ranked matches earns the player ranking points and leaderboards display the overall ranking of each player.
title: Grand Slam Tennis

description:
Tamagotchi: Party On! is a party game with Tamagotchis as its characters. The President of Tamaworld will be elected soon, and it must be who will prove the highest skillfulness in a series of contests and challenges, as well as good-heartedness. Thereby, the player's character, picked from a selection of Tamagotchis, will pay any effort to do an effort to meet people on the city's streets helping and comforting them, gaining popularity, as well as succeed in the mini-games. One minigame is Spot the Dessert: a sweet is displayed shortly, then three appear, one identical to the first and the two other ones resembling only. The player has to spot the equal one. In Rock, Paper, Scissors the game is the well-known classic game of rock paper and scissors. Change the Time requires to set both of a clock's hands correspondingly to those of another clock lying beside. Water Pump is about holding the Wii Remote horizontally, correctly aim the hose and pump it to water flowers.

Every minigame focuses on making use of Wii Remote's motion detection in this title released for the console's launch in Japan; each is also introduced by a screen explaining how to play.
title: Tamagotchi: Party On!

description:
Nerf N-Strike Elite, the sequel to Nerf N-Strike, is an on-rails shooter where the player can select their hero out of four N-Strike Elite agents, each of whom is equipped with a specific gun to shoot Elite darts at an army of ill-intentioned robots. Those are also the only projectiles the enemies will fire. The gist of the game is the variety of weapons: over 25 guns can be of avail to the dauntless agents, some of them being purchasable, some having to be unlocked in different ways; moreover, they all are capable of being customized, and enhanced by power-ups.

In addition to Story Mode, there is Blasting Range, a score attack mode played on a brief course. Some areas are only available through playing the cooperative mode for two players; up to four players can join the adventure.

Controls are given by the Wii Remote or by a bundled blaster, the Nerf Switch Shot Ex-3 which houses the Wii Remote. It is an enhanced version of the blaster that came with the preceeding iteration in the series: a red decoder lens attached to it will reveal otherwise-invisible game items such as hidden passages and enemies' weak points.
title: Nerf N-Strike Elite

description:
FIFA Soccer 09 All-Play is the Wii version of FIFA 09 and part of EA's Wii-dedicated All Play franchise with 500 licensed teams.

Specific content to the All-Play variant of FIFA is:* Footii Mode that is played by two teams which count eight players each instead of 11, and have an appearance modelled on Wii's Miis (with a Mii representing Ronaldinho, Rooney and others for other licensed football stars, as teams captains: they can be used by the player once winning a match against their team);

  • All-Play, an elementary control mode in which it is the CPU to move players on the field, while the unlearned player has merely to push buttons and perform gestures with the Wii Remote without dealing with the Nunchuk;

  • Table football, no more no less than a table football game (with 13 characters for each team, unlike 11 as in the real table football) displayed by a top-down view, given extra frenzy by peculiar balls such as one becoming invisible after it is kicked, or a rocket-ball.

  • Boot It, a simultaneous shooting frenzy that the player can take part in as one of the shooters shooter or the goalkeeper

New from the previous instalments of the series on the Wii is the possibility to play with the GameCube Controller or Classic Controller for a more traditional gaming experience. The Manager mode features a Wii-specific interface.
title: FIFA Soccer 09 All-Play

description:
Nine years later, Ready 2 Rumble: Revolution continues the arcade-style Ready 2 Rumble boxing game series. One minute and a half separate the time of boxers' arrival in the fighting arena (welcomed by fireworks) and the «Fight!» moment. The fighting interface offers varied possibilities as regards dodging and blocking attacks, as well as attacking. Offensive options include standard punches, uppercuts, roundhouses and power moves, each tied with a gesture of the player: everything is in fact done uniquely by the Nunchuk and waggling the Wii Remote. Performing the right actions timely is rewarded by the game adding a star to a meter: when it is full, Rumble Mode is entered, getting herculean strength.

Boxers skills are defined by three parameters: power, speed and defense. They develop following from how well the player does in some training minigames. Game modes are Arcade, Quick Fight (versus the CPU or another player), Championship, Team Fight, Tournament, Create a Boxer (items are unlocked gradually by reaching achievements) and Mini Game (to develop one's boxer's skills). A tutorial and a register of records are also available. Options allow choice regarding the number of rounds (from 1 up to 12), round duration (from a minimum of 30 seconds to 3 minutes), maximum number of knockdowns (from 1 to 6), level of difficulty (there are five) and handicaps for either player.

Boxers are imitations of renowned people from the show in facial features, while their names (Syphon Cruel, Kaiser Hong, Stoney Rigatoni — of obvious Italian descent —, Dragon Chew, et alii) are suggestive of their origin or related to their body shape. Secret fighters are unlockable by completing the Championship Mode.
title: Ready 2 Rumble Revolution

description:
Star Ving is a fabulous world composed of many islands all connected by sparkling rainbows, house to the Munchables, the quenchless creatures that love eating more than anything in the world. Their most highly treasured possessions are the Legendary Orbs, keeping their lands thrifty and rich of foods. The Great Elder governs over his happy people, wielding his wisdom: repose reigns. One day, their gleeful lives changes all of a sudden: a mysterious fleet of extraterrestrial spaceships surrounds the islands, taking over the Legendary Orbs. The aliens in the UFOs are able to avail themselves of the awesome energy from the Orbs, acquiring unbelievable power and beginning their descent on Star Ving. It is a dreadful army: treacherous-looking, fear-inspiring alive strawberries, peaches, eggplants, watermelons, apples, rice balls, magic mushrooms and more many other ones than it could be believed, all captained by Don Onion, known in the whole universe for the utmost mercilessness of his. «What will we do?», wonders the Elder in dismay, when... unexpectedly he is told that the invaders are tasty, and a flash of genius makes dismay hope: if enemies are tasty, they should be eatable! Now the Munchables know what to do.

In The Munchables the player is given control over one of the two Munchables summoned by the Great Elder — the belligerant Chomper, a male one, and the pinkish Munchy, a female —, and has to go around and through levels devouring the hostile legions of fruits and vegetables. The playing character in the game has a level: trying to swallow enemies of a level higher than Chomper's or Munchy's will end with them being repelled and stroke, yet it is possible to perform a dash attack that will split them into creatures of a lower level, therefore edible. As they eat, Munchables obviously grow and level up, getting able to gorge bigger enemies. On the completion of a level, the player's performance will be subjected to evaluation: a bonus item is the reward for high enough grades, most of the times consisting in an accessory to embellish Chomper or Munchy.

Controls depend upon the Remote and the Nunchuk: the player uses the analog stick to move the character; moves the Remote upwards to jump -tilting the stick to make the jump a forward or an on-a-side one; to eat a space invader, moves in the direction of it and presses the A button when in the vicinity of it; holds Z on the Nunchuk to lock on an enemy as their target; holds down A and, when having charged it enough, unleashes the Turbo Eat power to gourmandise all the unlucky enemies in a row realizing a combo; presses B to strike it by the dash attack parting it, when coming into an enemy of a level superior than theirs. It is possible for two players to join forces in a co-operative mode, as well as to play Mirror mode, in which stages are changed in the manner of an image reflected by a mirror and a stringent time limit compels the player to haste.
title: The Munchables

description:
Deca Sports 2 is a collection of the following sports games:* Darts

  • Dodge ball
  • Ice hockey
  • Kendo
  • Mogul skiing
  • Petanque
  • Road racing
  • Speed skating
  • Synchronized swimming
  • Tennis

For every game, several playing options are offered: Open Match, League (a competition featuring four teams), Tournament (a variety of tournaments), Challenge (a selection of minigames). Game modes are Single Play, Team Play (it is possible to compete with other players online — only with the U.S. version of the game, however — and offline, teaming up with or challenging one another). There is also the Locker Room, where teams and characters are edited, picking colors and emblems, deciding names and personalising players' appearance and attributes, tutorials for every game can be watched as well as records.
title: Deca Sports 2

description:
Deca Sports 3 is the third instalment in the Deca Sports series on the Wii and the fourth one on the whole.

The 10 sports included are:

  • air racing
  • fencing
  • freestyle kayaking
  • giant slalom (skiing)
  • halfpipe (snowboarding)
  • lacrosse
  • log cutting
  • racquetball
  • springboard diving
  • volleyball (indoor)

Game modes are still Open Match, League, Tournament and Challenge (made up of minigames for all the games). Teams' colors, logos, names, players' attributes are still customisable. Introduced for the first time is the Wii MotionPlus compatibility for advanced controls, while the game is still playable by simpler controls that are alike with the previous iterations'. Wi-fi online gaming is available worldwide, independently from the release country of the game: sports enjoyable by the Internet are:fencing, lacrosse, racquetball and volleyball; every sport has an online leaderboard. New is, as well, a Master sub-option for the Open Match, offering a stiffer degree of challenge.
title: Deca Sports 3

description: Wacky World of Sports presents a collection of eccentric sports taken from disparate countries in the world. The player can try themselves at Baseball Blast, Card Boxing, Cheese Rolling, Extreme Ironing (where the ironing is done while falling from the sky), Furniture Racing (which sees you ride, among the other things, a sofa, a toilet, a treadmill), Ice Golf, Log Cutting, Lawnmover Racing, Mud Sliding, Tuna Tossing (a hammer throw game, just with tuna in place of the hammer), in either single-player mode or in competition with up to 3 other human players, choosing one's playing character among four ones (plus some that may be unlocked) as bizarre as the sports they practice. The main single-player mode is the World Tour: achievements there unlock more wacky characters. There are also minigames for the multi-player mode.
title: Wacky World of Sports

description:
Learning With the PooYoos: Episode 3 faithfully follows in approach atmosphere and purposes the antecedent Learning with the PooYoos games. Infants can familiarize themselves with the letters of the alphabet, numbers, names, simple objects and their use, while enjoying assorted recreative activities, all in the company of many baby animals, centred around musical instruments, plants, shapes and colours. The friend animals can also be presented with gifts, and given aid in opening the giftboxes: many marvels will come out that will astound the children.

The game is specifically suggested for children that have not learnt reading yet. Two different levels of interactivity, Young PooYoo and Big PooYoo, are meant to suit every children's needs according to the age and progress in learning of theirs.

In Europe, the game is available with voices and text in Dutch, English, French, German, Italian and Spanish. The American version is in English, French, and Spanish.
title: Learning with the PooYoos: Episode 3

description:
A series of meteors and a main one huger than all the others are plunging towards the Earth. The game's hero is in urge to earn as much money as possible within a week to purchase from a TV shopping channel the Transformowatch, the ultimate anti-meteor tool which will transform the protagonist into a super hero letting him/her save the world.

Money is earned by attaining good results in a collection of minigames, that are what the game consists of; the better the results, the more the gain. Among the eccentric unheard-of occupations, to be a monster in a haunted house, a sumo referee, a red-carpet celebrity interviewer, make-up artist, stunt person, and many more ones. Three game modes compose the gaming offer of Help Wanted: 50 Wacky Jobs.* Employment Office, the story mode;

  • Career Fair, a practice mode for those minigames formerly reached in the story mode, that you can play with Mom Grandpa or Grandma as the rivals of yours;
  • Job Battle, a double-player competition mode which in turn offers a set of rules and game options:
    • Free For All;
    • Goal Money, whose winner is the first to earn the amount of a previously set pay cheque;
    • Total Money, seeing the contenders trying to attain more money than one another along a defined number of rounds;
    • Wins, where the challengers select how many wins are necessary to achieve victory.

For each job, several levels of expertise can be achieved, giving access to different levels of difficulty: a higher level will grant chance for higher rewards. As regards the TV, there is not only the shopping channel. The Memorial Channel sells items to be displayed in the memorial hall alongside a collection book which records visitors. The Support Channel is where items giving aid in duties are sold, while Uniform Channels offers new uniforms.

Name and sex of the hero in the game are initially unspecified: it is to the player to assign such characteristics to him/her. All the game is played by Wii Remote and Nunchuk: some minigames require either one or the other, some require both.
title: Help Wanted: 50 Wacky Jobs

description:
This compilation comprises the following two games:* Sonic and the Secret Rings

  • Super Monkey Ball: Banana Blitz
title: SEGA Fun Pack: Sonic and the Secret Rings / Super Monkey Ball: Banana Blitz

description:
In Super Monkey Ball: Step & Roll AiAi and the monkey friends of his (MeeMee, GonGon, Baby, and, for the first time, Jam) once more find themselves enclosed in balls, and once more have to be driven to the exit point of each of many courses. The in-ball characters are made roll to the goal by inclining the stage in any direction by less or more degrees. New from the preceding instalments of the series is the possibility to use the Wii Balance Board to perform in-game jumps, while the inclination of the playfield is still given moving the Wii Remote however; it is possible to make no use of the balance board at all. More or fewer obstacles are scattered through the courses depending upon the control method chosen, since using the balance board makes it more demanding to play per se.

The single-player mode consists of levels bracketed in the number of ten in a quantity of themed worlds; each world is regarded as unrelated with the others, and, since that, the completion of it will lead to the game's credits (that are not capable of being skipped). Levels can be played in co-operative mode: one will use the Wii Remote, one the balance board. More obstacles are placed into levels if two players co-operate. Multi-player mode can be joined by up to four players and makes use of split-screen view to display the action. Marathon mode demands to live without dying even once through the first half of game's levels, the second half of them, or all of them one after the other. There are minigames designed for one, two, and up to four players (to play each with a Wii Remore, or a player using the Wii Balance Board and the others up to three Wii Remote) to battle against each other.

Indicators shown (not optionally) on screen during the game play are: the speed meter on the bottom left, the number of lives and bananas gathered (an extra life is awarded for each 20 bananas gathered, unlike for 100 as in the series' origins) and the current score on the top right, the timer on the top left (1 minute is the time given to complete a stage). Stages are named and not merely numbered. The fifth level in each world is a bonus stage with fifty bananas to take. The score on levels' end results from Time Score (a hundred points per each second left) added to Stage Score (a hundred multiplied by the stage number points) and Clear Score (equal to Stage Score diminished by a hundred points and a hundred points for each bonus stage played in that world world), thus valuing swiftness.
title: Super Monkey Ball: Step & Roll

description: Logic Puzzle Series Vol. 1: Sudoku is a Sudoku game. Numbers are placed in grids by the Wii Remote. Four difficult levels provide different measures of challenge. Beside the main game mode, there is a level editor, as well as a two-player mode which sees the contenders compete with one another, and a speed play mode revolving around solving the problems as speedily as one can. A tutorial mode allows the ignorant of Sudoku to familiarize themselves with it.
title: Puzzle Series Vol. 1: Sudoku

description:
Puzzle Series Vol. 2: Illust Logic + Colorful Logic is a compilation of picture crosswords puzzles. A picture crossword consists of a grid divided into lines and columns of uniform squares: for each of those a series of numbers is given, telling how many of the squares have to be filled and how many sequences of filled squares have to be there: «2 5 1» will signify that a group of 2 filled squares, one of five, and a single one ought to be placed in the column or row, with unknown amounts of blank spaces beetween each group. A picture will eventually result from completing the puzzle (in the specific case of this game, some of them will portrait in sprite graphics popular Hudson game's characters).

Standard Mode sets grids of four sizes (5x5, 10x10, 15x15 and 20x20) before the player. Challenge mode introduces power-ups, a time in which as many riddles as possible have to be completed a time reward and penalty for — respectively — any rightfully and mistakenly filled space in order to salt the traditional quiet reflective experience of picross. In this mode grid size is limited to 15x15. Besides, there are a level creator and, as it is customary for the Puzzle Series franchise, a tutorial mode for the uninitiated to start grasping the essentials of picross.
title: Puzzle Series Vol. 2: Illust Logic + Colorful Logic

description:
This collection comprises the transpositions of the arcade version of three shoot-'em-up games by Milestone:

  • Chaos Field
  • Karous
  • Radirgy
title: Ultimate Shooting Collection

description:
The Milestone Shooting Collection 2 includes all games present in Ultimate Shooting Collection, with the addition of:

  • Illvelo Wii
  • Radirgy Noa
title: Milestone Shooting Collection 2

description:
Grill-Off with Ultra Hand! is a game that centers around Ultra Hand which Nintendo released in 1966. Ultra Hand is a plastic arm that extents to grab far away objects, and this premise is central to the gameplay of Grill-Off.

Players use a virtual version of the Ultra Hand to grab pieces of meat off of various grills and place them on a plate in front of them, but don't let any meat burn or fall on the ground or it is game over. In single player the goal is to last a long as possible. In multi-player the goal is to score more points than your opponent within a 90 second round. The motion is simulated through a combination of the Wii Remote and the Nunchuk. They are aimed forward and then inwards simultaneously to mimic the motion.

The gameplay is very similar to Game and Watch games in that the goal is to get a high score, all the while having the difficulty ramp up during gameplay. The game is only available to Club Nintendo members.
title: Grill-Off with Ultra Hand!

alternate_titles.title: The Lapins Crétins : La Grosse Aventure

description:
Rabbids Go Home is the fourth entry in the Raving Rabbids series. Unlike the previous games, which were mini-game compilations, Rabbids Go Home is an action-adventure game with platforming and racing elements. The Rabbids, now living in "our" world, surmise that their home is the Moon. They decide to travel there by the only way they know how: building a large pile of junk so high that they will be able to climb up to the giant orb in the sky. In order to get the junk, the Rabbids travel through various urban environments in a shopping cart, collecting as much random stuff as they possibly can while avoiding an increasingly hostile human populace.

The player controls the shopping cart as the Rabbids move through each level. While holding down A, the cart picks up speed, but at the cost of losing control. When blue sparks appear under the cart, the player can press the B button to perform a boost, which allows the cart to jump over across gaps and other obstacles using ramps, or smash larger items into more grab-able pieces. The player can also yell at enemies, which either destroys them completely or knocks much of their clothes off. The player uses these and other moves to navigate through cities, shopping malls, office buildings, hospitals, and many more environments. The game includes a very eclectic licensed pop soundtrack as well as multiple ways to customize the Rabbids.
title: Rabbids Go Home: A Comedy Adventure

description:
Onslaught is a first-person shooter that centers around the Elite Interstellar Strike Force. The player is a member of the team sent to a research colony after contact was lost. Upon arrival the team is immediately attacked and all alien lifeforms need to be eliminated. The player needs to complete 13 levels grouped into different tiers and to progress all levels in a tier need to be completed, including a boss. In addition there are three difficulty levels. The game has the player move through the environment to reach another point, taking out objectives, or surviving for a allocated amount of time. The different weapons include guns and a laser whip. The game includes support for cooperative play, for up to four players with the Wi-Fi connection. Competitive deathmatch games are not supported.

The Nunchuk is used to move and the pointer function of the Wii Remote is used to aim. Motion controls are also supported by shaking to reload, throwing grenades and unleashing the whip. Insect blood can blind and damage the character and it needs to be wiped off with a swipe. When playing alone the team mates are controlled by the computer AI and they can be issued basic commands. Later in the game it is possible to drive a vehicle.
title: Onslaught

description:
This limited edition includes:

  • Cursed Mountain
  • Steelbook case with interior art
  • Two-sided bonus disc with 15 tracks of in-game music (CD side) and 5-part "making of" video (DVD side)
title: Cursed Mountain (Limited Edition)

description:
Karaoke Revolution Glee features 29 songs selected from the Glee series to sing in Karaoke.

The game has two special modes to play, Shooting star and Scrapbook modes.

In Shooting Star mode, the player can sing either solo or in a duet. Meanwhile, they can shoot the rising stars with the Wii-mote to get bonus points. In Scrapbook, getting high scores will unlock various items to create customized scrapbook pages.

The Tracklist goes as follow:

  • And I Am Telling You I Am Not Going
  • Bust A Move
  • Can’t Fight This Feeling (exclusive new clip)
  • Defying Gravity
  • Don’t Rain On My Parade
  • Don’t Stand So Close To Me Young Girl
  • Don’t Stop Believin’
  • Endless Love
  • Gold Digger
  • Hair/Crazy In Love
  • Hate on Me
  • I’ll Stand By You
  • I Say A Little Prayer
  • Imagine
  • Keep Holding On
  • Lean On Me
  • Leaving On A Jet Plane
  • My Life Would Suck Without You
  • No Air
  • Papa Don’t Preach
  • Proud Mary
  • Push It
  • Smile (Cover of Charlie Chaplin Song)
  • Smile (Cover of Lily Allen Song)
  • Somebody To Love
  • Sweet Caroline
  • Taking Chances
  • True Colors
  • You Can’t Always Get What You Want
title: Karaoke Revolution: Glee

description:
Once more, a young wealthy boy, Aidan, and a young girl and modest waitress, Lucy, find themselves on a deserted island (a seemingly deserted one, at least) after a wreck. While gathering resources to survive, day by day they will discover new areas of the island by exploring it and have to think over how to advance, that will be similar to read puzzles. Activities and actions necessary to survive, typical to the Lost in Blue franchise, such as making fires and fishing, can now for the first time in the series be performed by moving the Wii Remote in a way that imitates what the moves would be in reality. This time however, the protagonists have pet animals as companions in adventure to help them with their skills: for instance, they play music, dance, collect items that the human characters could not.

Like in previous instalments, there is an offer of mini-games (more than thirteen, this time); new is the possibility to play a selection of these cooperatively. The game is provided with more than one unique ending, and more than one single plot-line, in consequence of the character chosen as the main one.
title: Lost in Blue: Shipwrecked

description:
This compilation consists of six games released on the Game Boy, NES, SNES and Nintendo 64 from 1992 to 2000:

  • Kirby's Dream Land;
  • Kirby's Dream Land 2;
  • Kirby's Dream Land 3;
  • Kirby's Adventure;
  • Kirby Super Star;
  • Kirby 64: The Crystal Shards.

As an addition, there is a booklet telling the history of the franchise and a music cd with 42 remixed and not remixed sound tracks from many Kirby games, plus 3 bonus tracks.

The games are played holding the Wii Remote horizontally in the manner of a classic controller, to give a feel similar to how they were played on their original release. There is a challenge game mode, revolving around attaining high scores and consisting of three new levels that take inspiration from Kirby's Return to Dream Land.

In the in-game museum, trailers for every game in the Kirby's franchise history and episodes from the TV series can be watched, while manga featuring the orotund Nintendo mascot can be read as well; furthermore, game packages of all Kirby games are available for being viewed closely, rotating them as one wishes. Curious notions of history are given as well, such as that in 1994 the first genetically engineered tomatoes went on sale.
title: Kirby's Dream Collection: Special Edition

description:
Fluidity is a puzzle game for Wii. Its gameplay is based entirely around the Wii Remotes' tilt sensors. A magic book has been infected with a bottle of ink known as the Influence. In order to save the book from corruption, you must pick up the book in your hands and tilt it to move a source of water around its colorful pages.

You'll use this water to hit switches, collect gears and fish to open up new areas, and defeat the Influence's minions. In addition, tilting the book also controls various machinery, including a crane, a pinball machine, and a monorail.

The player uses the water to collect Rainbow Drops, which act as the main means of progression in the game. As more drops are collected, new areas of the book open up for the player to explore. The player also receives various powers along the way, such as the ability to change into solid and gas forms. Many of the raindrops can only be collected after the player has received these forms and their powers.
title: Fluidity

description:
WarioWare: D.I.Y. Showcase is a WiiWare game, the first WarioWare title for the format. It is designed as a showcase for all the WarioWare: D.I.Y. products, such as microgames, music and comics. The game features connectivity with the Nintendo DS game WarioWare: D.I.Y. New microgames, different from the ones seen in WarioWare: D.I.Y., come pre-loaded on this game, but additional games can be obtained from the DS, other Wii consoles, or from Nintendo via Nintendo WFC. The player can also send microgames to others from Wii to Wii, or from Wii to DS.

Microgames are organized by character: Wario-Man, Dribble & Spitz, Kat & Ana, and 18-Volt. Wario-Man microgames feature Wario himself, Dribble and Spitz microgames involve science fiction, Kat and Ana microgames involve animals, and 18-Volt microgames feature Nintendo products. This makes for a total of 72 microgames which differ from the the 90 microgames seen in WarioWare: D.I.Y..

After all microgames are accounted for, Shuffle Stages are unlocked. These stages feature all the microgames in the game. Upon completing five microgames, the speed gets higher.
title: WarioWare: D.I.Y. Showcase

description:
Rune Factory Frontier's story begins with the hero Raguna traveling to the village of Trampoli in search of his missing friend Mist. However, once he finds her, she reveals that she has been hearing the calls of someone in her dreams. Raguna investigates for her and discovers that the mysterious whale shaped island over the village not only can speak but is in danger of falling and destroying Trampoli. Now Raguna must solve the mysteries of Whale Island as well as explore Trampoli's dungeons to find a solution to the danger that plagues the village.

Rune Factory Frontier was the first of the series to be released on the Wii. Much like its Nintendo DS counterparts, you own a farm, can grow crops, befriend villagers, get married and fight in dungeons. One major difference in Frontier compared to the previous games is the introduction of the Runey system, a mini-ecosystem you must manage that can either help or hurt crop growth. This particular game reprises many familiar faces from the first game on the DS, including Mist, Rosetta, Melody, and Lara. However, there are also many new bachelorettes for you to choose from. Another feature added with this game are the animated cutscenes for events and first meetings with the girls. While there is voice acting in this game, not every line of dialogue is done.
title: Rune Factory: Frontier

description:
Benjamin Blümchen: Törööö im Zoo is a minigame collection. The player spends some time in the Neustädter Zoo with Benjamin the elephant and his friend Otto. The player guides the two friends to the zoo exhibits to play minigames. For each mastered difficulty level of a minigame he receives a reward.

The player has 60 animal stickers to unlock in a scrapbook by completing minigames (one reward per difficulty).
title: Benjamin Blümchen: Törööö im Zoo

description: This game is one of three Pokémon Mystery Dungeon titles for the WiiWare format. Like the Pokémon Mystery Dungeon games before them, they are very similar, yet have key differences. In this case, the differences are names and layouts of dungeons, playable Pokémon, and Pokémon available as recruits. Playable Pokémon and partners are chosen rather than taking a quiz. Susume! Honoo no Bōkendan has the following playable Pokémon: Charmander, Vulpix, Growlithe, Eevee, Cyndaquil, Teddiursa, Torchic, Chimchar, and Buneary. It should also be noted that these games are not as plot-based as previous games in the series.
title: Pokémon Fushigi no Dungeon: Susume! Honoo no Bōkendan

alternate_titles.title: Mario & Sonic Bei Den Olympischen Winterspielen
Mario & Sonic Op De Olympische Winterspelen

description:
Mario & Sonic at the Olympic Winter Games is a sports game with the official license of the 2010 Winter Olympic Games and a crossover franchise from the Mario and the Sonic universe similar to Mario & Sonic at the Olympic Games.

It takes place at the Vancouver Winter Olympics of 2010. Like the previous game, the 27 events are presented as motion-based mini-games. Aside from the main events there are a series of Dream Events that have enhanced features and visuals. Some of the events can optionally be played using the balance board peripheral. Events include for instance skiing, snowboarding, bobsleigh, ice hockey, figure skating and more. The games can be played individually or in a festival mode that spans 17 days.

You can go shopping for various items to use in the game including costumes for your Miis and decorations for your equipment. Bowser Jr, Donkey Kong, Metal Sonic, and Silver have been added as playable characters. Multiplayer is available through cooperative and competitive game modes.
title: Mario & Sonic at the Olympic Winter Games

description:
This classic edition comes in a cardboard box and includes:

  • GoldenEye 007
  • Limited edition golden Classic Controller Pro
  • Code to immediately unlock the game's multiplayer Classic Conflict mode without having to reach level 35
title: GoldenEye 007 (Classic Edition)

description:
Red Steel 2 is the sequel to Red Steel and just like the original game it is a brawler played from a first-person perspective. The game trades the modern day urban setting for an Old West environment mixed with Eastern influences and even some science-fiction elements. It also introduces a new story not related to the first game. The visual design has been changed from a realistic style to a looser cel shaded design. The unnamed male protagonist is the last member of the Kusagari clan. After a period of exile, he returns to his desert home city Caldera, where he finds out that his clan has been exterminated and the city taken over by the Jackals gang. As they hunt him down, he barely escapes but loses his treasured Sora katana to them. Freeing his old swordsmaster Jian, he borrows his sword to take on the task of retrieving the katana and vanquishing the gang of bandits led by their leader Payne who conspires with Shinjiro, the main antagonist and a former member of the Kusagari who killed almost everyone to reveal the mysterious katana's powers.

The main story consists of different missions that are listed on a blackboard in a safe house. The hero does not have to work alone, he is assisted by the young Asian girl Tamiko, Jian and the drunk sheriff Judd who contribute to the story. Once the safe house is left, various Jackals can be engaged alternating between sword fighting and shooting. Up to six enemies on-screen can be fought at once and enemy packs can go up to twenty. Next to attacking, the sword can also be used to deflect bullets. New weapons, techniques and armors can be earned and upgraded by progressing through the game in exchange for money. Cash can be found in every level hidden in bags, safes, boxes, but Jian also provides it after successful moves and combos. Additional money can be earned through optional side missions. Judd's shop offers a rifle and a machine gun in addition to the regular pistol. The focus is however largely on the swordfighting. The visited scenery eventually moves on from the dusty town to lush gardens and train sequences. Often there are bosses at the end of levels that are much harder to defeat. The direction for quests is marked on a mini-map through a green arrow and after completion the hero need to travel back to the home base. Later levels also introduce small puzzle elements.

As the first game to support the Wii MotionPlus add-on peripheral, the control detection is more refined than in games with a regular controller. Optionally a Relaxed configuration can be enabled to increase the sensitivity so as to make a smaller and less-fatiguing arm reach possible.
title: Red Steel 2

description: Ikuzo! Arashi no Bōkendan is one of three Pokémon Mystery Dungeon titles released as WiiWare. Like the Pokémon Mystery Dungeon games before them, they are very similar, yet have key differences. In this case, the differences are names and layouts of dungeons, playable Pokémon, and Pokémon available as recruits. Playable Pokémon and partners are chosen rather than taking a quiz. Ikuzo! Arashi no Bōkendan has the following playable Pokémon: Squirtle, Totodile, Wooper, Phanpy, Mudkip, Azurill, Wynaut, Piplup, and Riolu. These games are not as plot-based as previous games in the series.
title: Pokémon Fushigi no Dungeon: Ikuzo! Arashi no Bōkendan

description: Pokémon Fushigi no Dungeon: Mezase! Hikari no Bōkendan is one of three Pokémon Mystery Dungeon titles released as WiiWare. Like the Pokémon Mystery Dungeon games before them, they are very similar, yet have key differences. In this case, the differences are names and layouts of dungeons, playable Pokémon, and Pokémon available as recruits. Playable Pokémon and partners are chosen rather than taking a quiz. Mezase! Hikari no Bōkendan has the following playable Pokémon: Pikachu, Meowth, Psyduck, Pichu, Togepi, Mareep, Elekid, Shinx, and Pachirisu. These games are not as plot-based as previous games in the series.
title: Pokémon Fushigi no Dungeon: Mezase! Hikari no Bōkendan

description:
For the 30th anniversary of Bibi Blocksberg, KIDDINX released Das große Hexenbesen-Rennen, a flying broom racing game geared towards the entire family. The player can choose between six broomsticks, each with its own particular flight mechanics, and six different characters, including Bibi herself. Extra witch potions can be used to create an advantage over the other players or escape a tight situation, such as a magical fog blocking the view. A number of golden brooms are hidden in every world. Finding them will unlock new race tracks.

The game contains twelve courses scattered over three "worlds": Neustadt, Schloss Klunkerburg and Blocksberg. There are three modes (Quick Race, Trophy Race and Time Trial) and the game has a multiplayer component as well.
title: Bibi Blocksberg: Das große Hexenbesen-Rennen!

description: Are you up for a rain dance in the savannahs of Africa, seal curling in Antarctica or a noodle duel with aggressive ninjas in Asia? As you might have guessed, Play the World is a collection of 12 skill games scattered over all of the world's six continents. The gameplay is varied, featuring rhythm games, food fights and races among others. The players that manage to collect the most points, win medals and unlock new games and costumes for their characters. It is controlled with the Wii remote and Nunchuk. In addition, some games can be controlled with the Wii Balance Board. The game can be played either alone or in multiplayer for up to four people.
title: World Party Games

description:
Art of Balance is an stacking puzzle game. The player is given a set of shapes to carefully place onto a platform slightly above a bowl of water. The level is won when all the shapes are balanced successfully for 3 seconds and lost when an object hits the water. There are 100 levels for the player to complete.

The game includes two multiplayer modes; a co-operative mode where a second player may join the game at any time and a split-screen versus mode where two players must stack all their shapes before their opponent.
title: Art of Balance

description:
In this party game for the Wii, players compete with and against their favorite Disney Channel characters. Players can even use their Miis!

Disney Channel: All Star Party features locations from a variety of Disney Channel shows and a mix of characters. The gameplay for each mini game reflects the theme of each environment (e.g. in a Wizards of Waverly Place game, you compete as students creating magical mischief while the teacher is not looking. If he catches you he will freeze you with his magic wand). Most mini-games are short, as is typical with the party game format.
title: Disney Channel: All Star Party

description:
In Muscle March, a team of international bodybuilders find out that their protein powder has been stolen, while they were busy flexing their muscles. They must give chase to the malevolent thief and recover it. The player chooses to control one of these seven bodybuilders, and together with several other team-mates follows the thief as he smashes his way through the walls of the level. While plunging into the walls, he strikes different poses and the bodybuilders must copy them if they want to pass safely. The player can match one of the four poses using the Wiimote and Nunchuk.

One by one, all the other bodybuilders slip on banana peels and fall graciously out of the race, while the thief gets gradually faster. Eventually, the player will remain the last one standing and will have to perform a takedown on the culprit by furiously shaking both the Wiimote and the Nunchuk. If this fails, the race continues until another opportunity arises. Hitting a wall removes one of five stamina points. Once all the stamina is lost, it's game over, but the same stage can then be replayed with maximum stamina. The single-player mode features three levels (City, Village and Space Station) with three stages each. The multiplayer mode (Endless Rush) is an endless rainbow level where the speed increases by 5 or 1 MPH after every five walls. Up to four players take turns to see who can survive the longest.

sample_screenshots.caption: Endless Rush or the multiplayer mode.
Abebe was lost in a glorious battle against the wall.

title: Muscle March

description:
A follow-up to Karaoke Revolution: Glee, featuring once again the New Direction glee club of McKinley High-school.

Scrap Book mode is yet again available to reach new achievements and collect unlockable items. A new feature, the vibrato indicator, helps the players develop their singing skills. Up to four players can join and compete in Shooting Star Mode.

This new installment in the Karaoke Revolution series feature 20 all new track to sing to:

  • "A House Is Not a Home" - Dionne Warwick
  • "Bad Romance" - Lady Gaga
  • "Beautiful" - Christina Aguilera
  • "Beth" - KISS
  • "Dream a Little Dream of Me" - The Mamas & the Papas
  • "Dream On" - Aerosmith
  • "Gives You Hell" - The All-American Rejects
  • "Good Vibrations" - Marky Mark and the Funky Bunch featuring Loleatta Holloway
  • "Hello, I Love You" - The Doors
  • "Ice Ice Baby" - Vanilla Ice
  • "Jessie's Girl" - Rick Springfield
  • "Like a Virgin" - Madonna
  • "Over the Rainbow" - Israel Kamakawiwo'ole
  • "Pink Houses" - John Mellencamp
  • "Shout It Out Loud" - KISS
  • "The Boy Is Mine" - Brandy and Monica
  • "The Lady Is a Tramp" - Sammy Davis, Jr.
  • "To Sir, with Love" - Lulu
  • "Total Eclipse of the Heart" - Bonnie Tyler
  • "U Can't Touch This" - MC Hammer
title: Karaoke Revolution: Glee - Volume 2

description:
Madden NFL 10 is the 2009 installment of the Madden NFL franchise, the officially licensed game of the NFL. The game, as with all recent previous installments in the series, was released for all major console platforms of the time.

The Wii version of the game introduces a new accentuated 'cartoony' visual style exclusive to the Wii. It also introduces several new game modes and other enhancements, including a new tournament style mode called 'Madden Showdown' which encourages players to bet on the outcome of individual matchups, a new cooperative 'Season Mode', and a new passing control system that allows players to pass the pall by using the Wii Remote to point at the receiver that they wish to pass the ball to. Another addition, 'Spotlight Moments', focuses the camera on pivotal moments in the game and slows down time to allow the player to affect the outcome in various special ways.
title: Madden NFL 10

description:
Madden NFL 11 is the 2010 installment of the Madden NFL franchise, the officially licensed game of the NFL. The game, as with all recent previous installments in the series, was released for all major console platforms of the time.

The Wii version of the game, besides retaining the cartoony visuals of Madden NFL 10 for the same platform, introduces a completely reworked Franchise Mode, which includes a new 3D user interface specific to each team. The interface changes as the game progresses depending on how successful the players are at managing their teams' franchise. The new Franchise Mode also includes feedback from, and interaction with, fans, and team staff members to guide the player through their franchise. It also introduces the GameFlow system, similar to the 360/PS3 game, which allows the player to quickly choose from plays recommended by the game AI, to provide a quicker gameplay experience.
title: Madden NFL 11

description:
Gameloft's Sexy Poker series comes to the Nintendo Wii. Six girls depicted in manga-style artwork are available to play strip poker with. Players can choose between Texas Hold'em Poker and Black Jack. After winning against a girl, they can check out the gallery to see her unlocked pictures.

Unlike previous installments, this game features no actual nudity.
title: Sexy Poker

description:
We Cheer 2 like its predecessor is a dance game where the player uses the Wii Remotes as pom-poms to make a customizable male or female cheerleaders dance to any of the game's 30 licensed tracks:

  • Get Ready For This – 2 Unlimited
  • Mickey – Toni Basil
  • Pump It (Clean Version) – The Black Eyed Peas
  • Run It Back Again – Corbin Bleu
  • Song 2 – Blur
  • Tubthumping – Chumbawumba
  • GNO (Girls Night Out) – Miley Cyrus
  • Real Wild Child – Everlife
  • Beat It (Feat. John Mayer) – Fall Out Boy
  • Glamorous (Clean Version) – Fergie
  • Get Down With This – Imani Coppola
  • Tell Me Something I Don’t Know – Selena Gomez & the Scene
  • Homecoming – Hey Monday
  • Let’s Dance – Vanessa Hudgens
  • Just Dance – Lady Gaga
  • Girlfriend – Avril Lavigne
  • La La Land – Demi Lovato
  • Leavin' (Radio Edit Remix) – Jesse McCartney
  • Closer – Ne-Yo
  • Whoa – Paramore
  • Higher Ground – Red Hot Chili Peppers
  • Pon de Replay – Rihanna
  • Walk This Way – Run DMC
  • Push It – Salt N Pepa
  • All Star – Smash Mouth
  • The Power – Snap!
  • So Bring It On – The Cheetah Girls
  • Doing It Right – The Go! Team
  • Popular – The Veronicas
  • Headstrong – Ashley Tisdale

Up to 4 players can play in co-op or competitive mode.
title: We Cheer 2

description: WSC Real 08 features six different rules including Snooker, 9-Ball and 8-Ball, authentic player body movement, professional commentary, audience interaction and replays for up to five turns. During your turn, you can use the "Coach" option at any time to see what the AI would do in your position; you can ask the AI to demonstrate an offensive shot, a defensive shot or a neutral shot, and then take the shot on your own. A comprehensive tutorial mode with dozens of video lessons is included.
title: WSC Real 08: World Snooker Championship

description:
This compilation of the Raving Rabbids contains the games:

  • Rayman: Raving Rabbids
  • Rayman: Raving Rabbids 2
  • Rayman: Raving Rabbids TV Party
title: Raving Rabbids Party Collection

description:
The Crystals: The Planet Eater is the final tale for Final Fantasy IV: The After Years. It consists of three tales presented as a single DLC for WiiWare version of the game.

The second moon that has been causing much trouble finally comes closer to the blue planet and starts pouring down meteors. Some locations are destroyed and new monsters appear. In the course of this tale all protagonists (over twenty characters) will reunite and solve the mystery behind the Mysterious Girl and the second moon. Aside from the main task there's an optional collector's quest and several optional bosses. The whole blue planet (and later - the moon) are accessible for free exploration.

If the player has finished any of the previous tales for Final Fantasy IV: The After Years the characters from those tales can be imported to provide the advantage over the hordes of monsters and also for some unique items and events. Otherwise the player will start the tale with low-level playable characters and default equipment.

The Crystals was originally released as three separate tales for mobile phones. These tales are: * Gathering Tale: The Moon's Gravity (Japanese title - Shūketsu Hen: Tsuki no Inryoku)

  • Final Tale Part One: True Moon (Japanese title - Shūshō Zenpen: Shingetsu)
  • Final Tale Part Two: Planet Eater (Japanese title - Shūshō Kōhen: Hoshikui)

sample_screenshots.caption: Now that the party is in free control of the airship the whole map is finally accessible

title: Final Fantasy IV: The After Years - The Crystals

description:
A prequel to Driver, the second Wii Driver game (developed specifically for this platform) is similarly based in San Francisco, but contains a specifically separate storyline to Driver: San Francisco. Featuring Detective John Tanner, the game follows his early years (1970s to 1980s) on the force. While still a uniformed police officer his partner is murdered in an unexpected drive-by shooting by Solomon Caine, an ambitious criminal who aims to disturb the fragile peace between the city's other gangs. With Tanner still a little green when it comes to undercover work, he's assigned back-up in the form of Tobias Jones, a more experienced cop. Tanner hits the streets as a gifted rookie and attempts to take down a crime syndicate controlling San Francisco’s underworld.

The game's story mode (built as a classic crime tale) has the player alternating between all three characters (thus told from the 3 perspectives): Tanner on his first undercover assignment is trying to find out who killed his partner; Tobias Jones (his partner) on the street gives back-up and chases leads; and Solomon Caine has a plan, but no one knows what it is.

The Wii version is a free-roaming action racing game in the vein of the original, does not include the other version's "Shift" mechanic, and allows players to use guns while driving. The player can drive numerous licensed cars across the open city of San Francisco, undertake various challenges and partake in an unlimited number of random chases, thanks to a consistent felony system. There is a total of 11 chapters that gives access to 30 story missions (race, chase or escape enemies, etc), 10 larger critical missions, 30 optional side missions and 58 unique awards linked to in-game activities. During the races, the opponents can either be taken down with melee attacks and in-car shoot-outs using a variety of weapons, or left behind with shunts and nitro boosts. Performing tricks and scoring awards are rewarded with points that, in turn, are used to upgrade weapons in various categories.

Multiplayer modes in offline split-screen allow up to 4 players, with game variants like Capture The Flag, Pass The Bomb, Gold Rush and Elimination, and a cops and robbers split-screen mode. At the same time, the drop in/out multiplayer co-op in story mode allows a buddy to help by taking control of a weapon.

This version of Driver: San Francisco also features Nintendo DS/DSi/3DS connectivity through download play, that can be used as a guide, weapon, make road blocks, look for police, or buy player 1 some more time through various mini games.
title: Driver: San Francisco

description:
Dance Dance Revolution is a Wii exclusive addition to the DDR series. It features the same dance moves as its predecessors, using an arrowed dance mat, but introduces the new Choreography mode. Using the Wii remote and Nunchuck like glow sticks, the player can now add arm motions (point up, down, forward or on the side, or describe half-circle motions) to their dance moves following the on-screen choreographed dance routine.

The game has a challenge feature that will prompt the player to play a specific song, play at a minimum difficulty level, and reach a minimum number of points that will have him earn bonus points to unlock new songs and additional items for custom avatars.

The track list includes over 40 songs, some by popular artists like:

  • Animal - Ke$ha
  • Bad Romance - Lady Gaga
  • Celebration - Kool & the Gang
  • Hey, Soul Sister - Train
  • The Way U Move - Bill Hamel & Derek James feat. Breanna Skiles

It is compatible with the Wii balance board.
title: Dance Dance Revolution

description:
Out on an island in the Pacific Ocean, toys known as Squeeballs are being produced. However, only the Squeeballs that pass rigorous quality assurance tests are allowed to be sold in stores. So it's up to the player, who takes on the role of a tester, to see which Squeeballs are up to snuff.

Squeeballs Party is a collection of over 150 mini-games. The game features eleven different game types with up to fourteen different challenges (variations) for each game type. The game types are as follows:

  • 10 Pin Bowling - Throw a bowling ball down a lane and knock down the bowling pins which have Squeeballs sitting on top of them.
  • Cannon - Players swat Squeeballs, that are fired from a cannon, with a racquet.
  • Cooking - Players follow recipes to make food by using motion control movements.
  • Paint by Squeeball - Slingshot Squeeballs to splatter them onto a canvas that has a drawing on it, in order to fill it in with color.
  • Shock - Players need to use precision movement in order to move a ring through a shock wire.
  • Stampede - Squeeballs rush toward the screen and the player must shoot at them before the entire screen fills up.
  • Crazy Lanes - Bowling that takes place on a lake of lava. Players actually get to take direct control of the bowling ball.
  • Feeding Frenzy - Players have to shoot the correctly colored Squeeballs into the mouths of the charging El Toro Squeeballs.
  • Pumping - Players inflate a Snorgle Squeeball with hot air and then guide it towards a target while it deflates in mid-air.
  • Golf - Slingshot a Squeeball into the air and then skip it on water while trying to land on a target.
  • Squeeball Testing Belt - Do various harm to Squeeballs as they come out of a conveyer belt by utilizing the correct motion depending on the Squeeball currently being tested.

The main gameplay modes offered include the Challenge Ladder mode, the Single and Party Game modes, and a Head-to-Head mode.

The game records the players high scores, keeps track of various statistics (such as how many Squeeballs were tested on), and the player can even unlock character bios for individual Squeeball types.
title: Squeeballs Party

description:
In the sequel to PokéPark Wii: Pikachu's Adventure, Pikachu comes to a new PokéPark with his best friend Piplup. They hear of an area there called Wish Park, full of fun and adventure. However, they find that Wish Park is actually a place where Pokémon are trapped and cannot leave. Furthermore, Reshiram and Zekrom have seen that a dark omen is about to fall on the PokéPark.

Playable Pokémon include Pikachu, Snivy, Tepig, and Oshawott. The player switches out members of their team to choose between them. Skill games return, Chase and Battle. During Battle, the player cannot switch Pokémon. Friend Pokémon can be used for aid once during a battle. Attractions also return, but are much less focused on and are much fewer in number.
title: PokéPark 2: Wonders Beyond

description: Active Life Explorer is a party game geared towards elementary schoolchildren, featuring a total of 24 mini games. The game requires the manipulation of both the Wiimote and the Active Life floor mat controller. It offers three main modes of play. Treasure Adventure allows players to create an avatar and explore different areas of the world to find treasure. Each level is a brief challenge that requires some physical activity to complete; for example, running across a collapsing bridge, swimming to a sunken ship, rappelling down a cliff, or fighting a giant squid. Free Play gives the player unrestricted access to all mini games, while Party Mode is a multiplayer component that supports up to eight players using four pads.
title: Active Life: Explorer

description:
Fit & Fun is a fitness game. After making a fitness test, the players are able to create their own individual work out plan out of 70 exercises. A work out consists of five parts: warm up, strength training, body shaping, recreation and fun. Every exercise is demonstrated by a male or female trainer. The exercises range from simple ones, including among many others, rope skipping and beach running to more exotic ones such as meditation during the recreational part and mini games like bobsledding and hang gliding.

The game was created in collaboration with fitness experts from the German Fit For Fun magazine. The players have their own virtual personal coach in the game and are able to train with a partner.
title: Fit & Fun

description:
The Voice of Germany is a game based on the identically-titled TV show. It's a family karaoke game produced and co-developed by Wired Production and Le Cortex.

In the first part of the game you are able to sing a song and revise if you sang out of tune. The game notices if you only hum and the famous coaches Nena, Xavier Naidoo, Rea Garvey (Reamonn) and The Boss Hoss will help you with their criticism and support.

There is a huge library of songs and you can expand it with DLCs. Four people at the same time can sing and play together. You are also able to record your songs

sample_screenshots.caption: Test your voice on this song (Bruno Mars-Grenade)

title: The Voice of Germany

description:
Atrévete a Soñar (Dare to dream) is a music game based on the Mexican telenovela of the same name. Players choose to be one of two main girls, Patito or Antonella, and get to perform songs from the show by singing, dancing, or both, for up to four players. The game includes a microphone and for the singing part the player has to maintain the correct voice pitch and length, shown through horizontal bars, similar to the SingStar series, while the lyrics scroll along in karaoke fashion. For the dancing part direction prompts appear on the screen and the player has to tilt the Wii Remote in the correct direction in a timely fashion similar to the Just Dance series. Meanwhile, the animated characters with the likeness of those in the show sing and dance along in the background.

At the end of the song the performance is rated. Characters can be customized based on 50 elements and the game contains 20 songs from the show, 10 scenarios, and 19 characters from the original series.
title: Atrévete a Soñar

description:
TRON: Evolution: Battle Grids is a game based on the movie TRON: Legacy. In the year 1988, the legendary champion TRON has left the Battle Grids tournament, and a new champion now has the chance to arise. For the first time an ISO (a program that hasn't been created by a user) might become the new champion.

The game features a variety of different Grid Games to play alone or with up to four player. The different Grid Games are Light Cycle arena, Light Cycle Races, Disc Arena, Light Runner Arena, Light Runner Races, HyperBall and Tanks. They can be played in Grid Games mode, Story mode or Championship mode. While the Grid Games mode is basically a free-play mode, the Story mode allows the player to create a custom ISO character and access scenario quests and other optional side-quests accessed from hubs such as TRON City to improve the ISO's stats and earn Bits to unlock new equipment and vehicles. The goal of the Story mode is to become the champion of the TRON Grid Games.

In Championship mode, the player selects four to eight disciplines that will be the challenge of the Grid Championship Game. This mode also allows up to four player to team up against AI or compete against each other.

Each Grid Game has its own gameplay, for instance:* In Light Cycle arena, the competitors must "derezz" (defeat) their opponents by making them hit the light trail that follows their Light Cycle.

  • Light Cycle races are simply a race to the finish line, but the player can still derezz their opponents or make them crash by bumping into them.
  • Disc Arena is a Disc fight duel in which the competitors must derezz their opponent by throwing a disc at them, or with hand-to-hand combat.
  • HyperBall is a volley-ball like sport where the panels on which the players stand can be destroyed by the ball. Scoring or making the opponent fall are the two ways to win.

Different game styles can be unlocked by playing the default games.
title: Tron: Evolution - Battle Grids

description:
Pirates PlundArrr is a side-scrolling beat em' up fantasy adventure game wherein you play as a pirate plundering the land and waters of the Caribbean. Play with friends to find Rudebelly, who stole an ancient artifact called the Sceptre of Power. It has the power to call forth undead creatures and dangerous bosses. Fight these monsters as you try to get your treasure back.

You can wield a diverse selection of weapons from daggers and axes to guns and turkey legs. Scattered objects such as barrels and treasure chests can be picked up and thrown at the enemy. The experience points you earn during the game levels up your character, giving him access to upgrades and special weapons. Collecting items such as bananas and hearts can replenish the health lost during encounters with the enemy. Up to four players can play together in the co-op mode of the game.
title: Pirates PlundArrr

description:
The Amazing Spider-Man for Wii is a modified version of the main console version. It shares the story (Spider-Man has to rescue Manhattan from the Virus which made Curt Connors to Lizard), voice-overs and level set-pieces. However, there is one very important difference: the absence of all open-world elements. Peter Parker's apartment serves as hub from where the player chooses the next destination. This is usually the next level or a boss fight, but there are also challenge maps (either defeating a number of enemies within a given time frame or stealthily knocking out enemies) available. Solving missions rewards experience points which are used to improve Spider-Man's abilities.

Combat is similar to the main version and still takes many cues from Batman: Arkham Asylum: Spider-Man quickly switches between enemies and punches them; when the spider-sense is activated he can dodge and perform a counter-attack. A not disrupted flow builds up a counter which, when high enough, is used to perform a powerful attack. The web rush ability slows down time and allows Spider-Man to pick a destination to swing to. This can be used for surprise attacks or quick retreats.
title: The Amazing Spider-Man

description: Climax Heroes W is an updated release of Kamen Rider: Climax Heroes released to tie in with the then-recent premiere of the Kamen Rider W TV show. It adds eight new playable characters including unlockables, and features a new mission-based story mode called "Climax Mode" that takes place in the Kamen Rider W world. The biggest change is the addition of non-Rider antagonists to the character roster.
title: Kamen Rider: Climax Heroes W

description:
Young brothers Asbel and Hubert Lhant are exploring the forbidden Lhant Hill when they stumble across a purple-haired girl, lying in a meadow of flowers. She doesn't remember anything about herself, so the boys decide to give her a name: Sophie. Along with their friend Cheria, the children quickly befriend her and a boy named Richard, the prince of Windor. But when the children are attacked by a strange monster, Sophie sacrifices herself for their sake and the group quickly separates. Asbel leaves to become a knight, beginning his training at the Knight Academy. Years later, Asbel is just about ready for knighthood. At the same time, strange otherworldly monsters begin to make appearances all over the planet, and the Sophie who was presumed dead years ago returns once again.

Tales of Graces is the twelfth game in the Tales series, following a format similar to its predecessors. Exploration takes place on a field where items can be collected or side-quests can be initiated; coming into contact with an enemy begins a battle. Battles follow the Style Shift Linear Motion Battle System, in which simple attacks and special skills are executed in real-time. Skills are performed through button combinations which may be mapped in menus beforehand, and are split into two categories: Assault Artes are special attacks done on the spot while Burst Artes are actions which must be charged, such as healing spells. The amount of attacks that can be performed in one combo is regulated by Chain Capacity, more frequently referred to in-game as CC. When CC is used up, it can be replenished by blocking, walking, or simply waiting. The number of CC available for each combo increases as characters level up, allowing for more powerful and intricate combos as more attacks are learned.

New to Graces is the Eleth Mixer. Obtained during adulthood, the Eleth Mixer serves three primary purposes based on the items which can be assigned to it: placing food in the Mixer gives that dish the opportunity to cook during battle, providing the party with its effects. Materials can be placed and duplicated in the Mixer, useful for farming rare materials. Lastly, books assigned to the Mixer give special bonuses to the party in and out of battle. Obtaining the Eleth Mixer also grants the party an Eleth Gauge during battle. Maxing out the gauge gives the party the chance to perform Mystic Artes, special attacks that are learned by each character through story events which deal damage based on how high the party's current hit count is.
title: Tales of Graces

description:
This Nintendo-exclusive release of a Need For Speed focuses on a Arcade-like gameplay. Although the graphics have a comic-style the cars are licenced.

The races include classical circuit races, K.O. races, time trials, and races where you have to pass a certain point at the highest speed possible. Also the Drag- and Driftraces introduced in The Need for Speed Underground series are here as well. In this part the police is present again providing high speed chases with the player with the possibility to take their side too.

New to the series are Power Ups which repair your car during an event for example since cars can get damaged even to the point that the performance is affected.

The action takes place on public roads which can be found in Singapore, Madrid, Cairo, Rio de Janeiro and Dubai.
title: Need for Speed: Nitro

description: Bust-A-Move Bash! is a real-time puzzle game in which the player controls a device called "pointer" at the bottom of the screen, aiming and releasing randomly colored bubbles upwards. Depending on the aiming, the bubbles may float up directly or bounce off the walls, changing their trajectory. The goal is to aim the bubbles in such a way that they will touch identically colored ones. When such bubbles form a group of three or more, they pop and disappear from the screen.
title: Bust-A-Move Bash!

description:
Monotone Princess is an action game based on the Soul Eater manga. As many people disappearances have been reported, the Shinigami school Shibusen's teachers decided to send their top students investigate. Masked creatures are gathering souls, and unlike Shibusen's Meisters and Weapons, they are not consuming these souls as they are captured, but are planning to use them for another purpose.

The player controls a Meister, either Maka, Black Star or Death the Kid, accompanied by their Weapon partner to fight those masked creatures. The game is separated in a number of missions leading to a boss fight. A number of foes, displayed in the lower-right corner, must be found and defeated in each stage. While exploring, the Weapon follows the Meister in human form, and changes into a weapon when enemies are encountered. Health is replenished by sun icons found by breaking crates lying around during exploration phases. Once the target number of defeated foes is reached, the level is cleared, and the player is rated on clear time, damage taken, number of hits and level bonus. The next mission can then be selected.
title: Soul Eater: Monotone Princess

description:
Valhalla Knights: Eldar Saga is a third person action RPG with a heavy focus on combat, much in the fashion of the Monster Hunter series, and leveling up your character.

The game is set in an ancient lands of Eldar where the races have divided and monsters roam the lands. You take on the role of, first, a male character and later on a female character to rid the world of monsters while doing quests for the townsfolk. As the game progresses, you can play the story through the perspective of a number of characters. Eldar Saga features a character creation system that allows you to choose from a variety of races and customize your character, after which you select from multiple classes, ranging from warriors to bards and priests to thieves, each with their own skill set.

Doing quests, gathering resources and building up your character are integral parts of the game. Upon accepting quests, you can choose to take a computer controlled partner with you, or a friend through the online Nintendo Wi-Fi connection.
title: Valhalla Knights: Eldar Saga

alternate_titles.title: Mario & Sonic ai Giochi Olimpici di Londra 2012
Mario & Sonic aux Jeux Olympiques de Londres 2012
Mario & Sonic bei den Olympischen Spielen: London 2012
Mario & Sonic en los Juegos Olímpicos - London 2012
Mario & Sonic nos Jogos Olímpicos de Londres 2012
